bibl.title: Letter from L.M. Fisher to Henry Rose Carter, November 3, 1922

div1.p: Fisher reports on malaria and mosquito conditions at some North Carolina sites.

div1.head: Letter from L.M. Fisher to Henry Rose Carter, November 3, 1922
div1.opener:
N. M. C.
JAMES A. HAYNE, M. D.
Secretary and State Health Officer
L. M. FISHER
Associate Sanitary Engineer
U.S. Public Health Service
In Charge Malaria Co-operative Work
State Board of Health
of South Carolina
DIVISION MALARIA CO-OPERATIVE WORK
Columbia Nov. 3, 1922.
Mid Waters
Fisher
Dr. H. R. Carter
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
I appreciate very much your letter of November 1st, en-
closing manuscripts regarding impounded waters. I have
gone over them hastily, and after studying them a little
more will return them to you.

I have practically finished my report on Marion but have
not sent it in yet. It is bulky and includes a lot of
matter that may be irrelevant, but as I understood Dr.
Fricks' instructions, he wanted me to prepare a report
about the way I have prepared this one. I did not include
any recommendations to be enforced in the pond itself,
for the reason that I did not find any breeding of im-
portance in the pond. I cannot help but feel that when
the pond is full, there will be much production in the
shallow water around Yancy's bridge. Just before the pond
rises in the spring of the year, say May, it might be
advisable to plough all the bottom land so as to get rid
of the grass and weeds. The pond is evidently usually
full from about June 1st to the middle of August or Sep-
tember 1st.

I will be glad to see you at Chattanooga and show you my
report and discuss matters with you.

Answering some questions. You asked in a former letter if
I met Miss Cora Brittan. I think I did. I think she is
in Dr. Jonas' office and told me her home was near Mr.
Bost's place. I think she is considerably above the
average in intelligence and will probably not miss an
opportunity to collect from the Power Company, if one
presents itself.

When returning to Columbia I stopped at Charlotte to see
-2-
Burkholder and Hutchison. The latter told me his father-
in-law told him of an outbreak of malaria on John's River
below Morganton. He knew no details about it.

I probably did not make myself clear with regard to the
seven cases occurring in 1919 more than two miles from the
pond. The implication was not that the malaria came from
the pond, but it was sightedcited by Dr. Long as evidence that
malaria not caused by the pond existed in that part of the country. before 1919.
After talking with the people at Charlotte and learning
that the ponds on Linville River and Paddy Creek began to
fill sometime in 1917 as the earth dams were being raised,
and since local labor may have been employed by the con-
tractor of this work, it is even possible that the pond
may have been responsible for some of this malaria occur-
ing at distances away from the pond.

You asked how far these seven cases were from the men en-
gaged in the construction work at the dam and power house.
Two cases were at Dysortville, 10 miles south of the pond;
four cases on Silver Creek, five miles southeast of the
pond; and one on Jamestown Road, three miles from Glen
Alpine.

It would be interesting to know whether there was an out-
break of malaria among the laborers in 1918 and 1919.

I expect to get to Chattanooga about one o'clock on Sunday,
November 12th, and expect to be at the Grand Hotel.
div1.closer:
Yours very truly, L. M. Fisher
Associate Sanitary Engineer.
